description:
While trying to attach more than one volume to an instance two volumes hung in an "attaching" state.   A volume-detach on that volume returns a 404  and a volume-delete returns a 500.    

It seems that a volume-force-detach is needed to clean up volumes in a hung state.
title: There is no way to recover/cleanup  a volume in an 'attaching' state

comments.content:
Dealing with a force detach:
The database has the status set to "attaching" and a storage repository may exist on the host.

A suggested process for cleaning up a volume stuck in an "attaching" state:

Check if a "storage repository" exist on the host
if it does
    remove it

update the volumes state in the db to "available"

without any pause and 8 of them hung in an "attaching" state.   I
created a new instance on a different host and tried the same
experiment again this time with a 20 second sleep between each
create/attach volume call.    I was able to get 4 attached with 6
hanging in the "attaching" state.

comments.content:
I think I have a simple and reliable way to reproduce.  Try attaching a volume to an instance that does not have a route to the nova-volume service.

I stumbled into this through a misconfiguration.  The fixed_ip range in my case is a private non-routable network.  I tried attaching a volume without configuring the nova-volume server to have a NIC on that private network and have this result.

Thanks!

comments.content:
If I understand the above correctly there are actually 2 issues described here:

1) That once the volume is stuck in "attaching" there is no good way to clean it up in Cinder.
2) It is easy to get Nova to leave volumes in such inconsistent states and there is

Pert 1) is has believe addressed at least to some extent by https://review.openstack.org/#/c/12004/, so I am tempted to mark this as fix committed, but it is an admin only fix so I will wait for cinder folks to confirm that they are happy that it indeed does address this bug.

The nova part of the bug needs more looking into. Currently (icehouse-3) nova would call cinder's "reserve_volume" (which will move the volume to the "attaching" state as described in the bug) in the API, and should be cleaning the state up on failure on the compute side of the "attach_volume" rpc call, from looking at the code. 

So the likely culprit at this moment may be some issues with messages getting through. I will try to reproduce what is described above with the current trunk (it's been a year and a half since this has been reported), and circle back here once I have more info.
